segments.text: This is a test.
You lived here after the mine shut down?
Oh yeah.
They run into that hole and they grind themselves in.
Put that a little deeper then.
Two men drove their Model T into the mine shaft?
Yeah.
Do you remember about what year that was?
No, I can't tell you exactly.
What, 1920s?
No.
They had a tipple over there.
They had a tipple.
How did that tipple work?
Exactly.
Well, they're made out of 12 by 12 straight up.
And there's four, six of them.
And then the rest of them.
Six 4 by 12s?
Huh?
Six 4 by 12s?
Okay.
And this was an engine, you could say.
Was it a steam engine?
Huh?
A steam engine?
A steam engine, yeah.
Where was the boiler?
Do you remember that?
The boiler?
They had a sawmill that belonged to the man who owned the coal mine, the coal mine owners.
They had a sawmill.
Why would they have a sawmill?
Well, to make some timber for the coal mines.
There used to be a lot of timber.
Cut their shore.
Did they use a steam engine again for that?
Okay, now what was the name of this mine site?
It's not the Black Diamond Mine.
No.
What was the Spanish name?
The Black Diamond is the name they gave the coal mines.
Of vogels.
Of vogels, okay.
But what did the Spanish people call this mine?
This one?
Yeah.
This other one, across here?
Right.
La recluta, we call in Spanish recluta, but that's the name of the people there.
La recluta?
Recluta.
Recluta.
Everybody know la recluta.
La recluta.
That would be... Jose Mireles.
Oh, Jose Mireles?
Yeah.
Yeah, over at the old Vogel mine, that's where he was trapped.
Yeah, that's the one.
See, that was the one, two, that was the third coal mine.
No, that was the fourth coal mine.
This was the third coal mine right here.
Okay, what we've been calling the Black Diamond Mine is La Recluta, and it was the third coal mine that the Vogels built, right?
Yeah.
The coal mines was over there.
This is the third coal mine they built.
And then there's another coal mine back in, I think, 1912.
It got full of water.
Okay.
It caught some men down there.
1913 is when it was.
1913, that's right.
It caught seven men and a mule.
Yeah.
We'll be over there in just a minute.
Now, Willinghampton used to live right there.
He used to live right along there.
There was cutting wood from Mr. Nowak.
Mr. Nowak?
Mm-hmm.
And early in the morning, they run in there.
With that Model T, right?
Mm-hmm.
How did they get that Model T out?
With the winch?
Yeah.
What do you remember about the mines?
What sticks out in your mind most about the mines?
What sticks out in your mind most about the mines?
All I can remember is that I worked hard to it.
How old were you when you first went down?
I was about eight years old.
You started at the brickyard when you were eight?
And then you moved into the mines?
No, I was working there in the coal mine.
I want to show you, if we go out there, I'll show you where the brick kiln was, and that's where the mines covered up.
You know how long the lake tank was over there?
Right, that clay pit, right?
Yeah, that's why I showed you them pictures a while ago.
Right, yeah.
Well, they used to get the dirt out into the big shade, you know?
Right.
And they had to get dry.
They made the bricks out of dry dirt.
Right.
Dry clay, right?
Yeah.
Well, you were eight years old when you went down into the mine?
Yeah.
Did your parents have to sign a paper?
No.
They used to not do that.
They used to not do that?
Yeah.
Well, what year would that have been if you were eight years old?
A little bit of trouble about that big.
You know what I do?
Just beat it over there in the coal mine.
That's the company.
But I got a little bigger than he.
They got me picking a shovel, and said a room or entry run like this, and another one run like this.
And they had a, they run a place like this for air.
See, they run, when you get so far, then they stop this thing up, and then you get out to this one.
I see.
So when you were eight years old, you just went down to your father.
You didn't really work.
Well, how old were you when you started?
About 12 years old.
About how many carloads a day could you by yourself fill up?
Oh, really?
Yeah.
Well, what year were you born?
Do you remember that?
1890, I was born in La Toscosa County.
That's outside of San Antonio.
Coal mines are there.
I see.
Outside of San Antonio.
So you were down in the mines in 1898.
And when you became 12 years old, you started digging yourself.
How long did you...
I didn't work there.
I didn't work, you know, I just went down to company with my father.
I am going to show you when we got out right back of where them cattle was at.
Right.
That was the first coal mine that my father came to work.
Because I don't remember because I was crawling then.
Right, right.
I see.
Well, when, did you ever work the mine actually yourself?
Did you go down and dig?
Yeah.
When did you start that and where?
I guess I was about 18 years old.
Which mine did you start at?
Well, we lived at Vogel's coal mine most of the time.
I worked on the Texas coal company, but I didn't work no time there.
A few months.
Well, when you were working at the Vogel mine when you were 18, about how many car loads a day?
Well, I could dig about 60.
About six?
About six tons of coal.
That's six tons of coal a day.
And how much would you get paid for that?
I think I was getting 20 cents.
20 cents a car.
Did they pay you every two weeks or every month?
Every two weeks.
Every two weeks?
Did you ever get cash for your pay?
Did you go to the commissary and order food?
Yeah, each one of the coal mines had a commissary.
Were you able to save money?
No.
I had no sense to save money.
What did you spend your money on if you didn't save it?
Well, I didn't save it because of what little work, you know, what little work I'd done.
Well, I let my mother have, buy groceries, things like that, clothes, things like that.
Until I married, then I began to work hard by myself.
And once you were, when were you married?
How old were you?
I married in 1914.
And then how many coal cars a day did you?
About the same.
About the same?
Yeah, about the same.
But most of the time, then after that, after marriage, I worked for a company, you know, a mule driver.
So you came out of the mines and worked?
On top or?
No.
Oh, you were a mule driver in the mines.
In the mines, yeah.
Did you get paid differently for being a?
Yeah, $2 and something.
I think $2 a day.
$2 a day.
So that would have been about $60 a month?
Huh?
About $60 a month?
Yeah, but we only worked five days.
Five days, okay.
Five days and a half during the summertime when they was using coal for this cotton gins.
Mm-hmm.
Then it's when we get more work.
But in the wintertime, we didn't get very much work to do.
Was there any time during the year that you didn't work at all in the mines?
No, I didn't work all the time.
Steady work that just is overtime work some seasons of the year when the cotton gins.
When the cotton gins was working, we'd get more work at the coal mine.
We worked five days.
Did you ever work six days a week?
No.
About how many hours a day would you work down in the coal mines?
Well, I think about eight hours.
I see.
What did you do on the weekends?
If you only worked five days a week, what did you do on the weekends?
Well, I'd play with the kids, play ball.
I worked some in Malakoff, Texas, too.
In Malakoff, okay.
That was every kind of work.
These coal mines out here, they're never blasting the coal out.
And it might have cost you this because that coal's too hard.
Maybe we can ask Tomas here, what kind of cooking ware did the women use in the mine camps?
Oh, well, you just, everything you can get.
Everything, flour, tables, bacon.
They used tin pots or iron pots?
No, they used, most of it was tin.
Tin?
Yeah.
You found some ceramics over there, you say?
Just enamelware, like china.
That's where the camp used to be.
You see, the camp used to be right along there.
Covered all that ridge back there, did it not?
Huh?
Covered this entire ridge, the crossover ridge.
No, we used to live, we used to have a house right over there.
Right just beyond those two trees, right?
But then this place didn't look like it, no.
Not what it was before.
You see, there was no wood in there.
All that place in there, there was no wood.
It's all cleared out.
Just two trees, I don't know.
How long ago was that?
Oh, it was 19...
The last time I worked for this company, 1925.
And where did you go after that?
I went to Malakoff.
In 1925, I went to Garrison, Texas.
Garrison?
Garrison.
Garrison.
Galveston or Garrison?
No, Garrison.
Garrison.
But I don't have a voice for Nacogdoches, but...
Right.
And then you came back.
When did you come back to Rockland?
Then I came back in 1930.
And what did you do then?
Then I went to work at the coal... See, 1930?
No, I worked on the railroad.
I worked about two months, maybe three months.
And then I went to picking cotton.
And then from there, after cotton was all picked out, I went to cutting wood.
Did you ever go back to coal mining?
No, there was no more coal mining then.
After 1925?
No, no, after 19...
34, 35 I think was the most coal mines.
Well, in the 1930s, you didn't work in the coal mines.
Yeah.
You did.
When you came back from Garrison.
When I came back to Garrison, I came back to this same place here.
And I stayed here about five or six months.
And then I went back to Malacca.
And I stayed in Malacca until 31, I think.
And then you came back.
And then came back, the coal mines was all gone.
I went to work for a railroad company.
In 1931, that is.
Yeah.
I see.
Entry, that's main.
Then they got places that comes out this way, they call them rooms.
Yeah.
Fingers.
Yeah.
And then another place comes in this way, and then here's where you get your air ventilator.
Did you stope it?
Huh?
Was it stoping?
How'd you mine it?
With a stoke?
With a pick.
With a pick?
Pick and a shovel.
You didn't use a drill?
Hammer?
No.
You didn't have steel drills?
No, this is all the coal around here is lignite.
Yeah, it's real soft.
Soft, yeah.
But still, it's hard.
Most of the coal that you can dig is about ten cars a day.
How much was in a car?
One ton.
One ton?
Don't turn a call for 20 cents.
